questions.text: 41-year-old Mr. Sharma had an influenza-like illness for one week, followed four days later by rapidly progressive, ascending motor weakness requiring mechanical ventilation. On physical examination, he is afebrile and has 3/5 motor strength in his extremities. A lumbar puncture is done and yields clear, colorless cerebrospinal fluid under normal pressure. This fluid has a slightly elevated protein concentration, but a normal glucose level, and a cell count with only a few mononuclear cells. He recovers in three weeks. If lymphocytic infiltrates were seen in peripheral nerves along with segmental demyelination at the time he initially saw his physician, what would be the most likely diagnosis?

Solution:

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to difficulty walking and frequent falls. One week ago, he had numbness in his toes and fingertips that progressed to lower-extremity weakness. He had an upper respiratory tract infection four weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. The patient has no bowel or bladder complaints. The examination shows muscle weakness in both lower extremities and absent knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally. The sensory examination is unremarkable. CSF analysis reveals: protein increased, WBC Normal , Glucose Normal . What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IVIG Patient is suffering from Guillain-Barré syndrome(GBS) As he has Acute, ascending, symmetrical paralysis,LMN type(Flaccid, absent DTR) Numbness in foot (some sensory symptom ,with intact sensation) History of Upper respiratory infection (trigger) . Also has increased protein with normal WBC count ( Albuminocytological dissociation ) -Treatment of GBS includes Supportive care (eg, monitoring of autonomic and respiratory functions ) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) -GBS autoantibodies are neutralized by anti-idiotypic antibodies present in IVIg OR plasmapheresis- removing autoantibodies by plasma exchange. -Both IVIG and plasmapheresis are equally beneficial and the choice of treatment depends on patient specific risk factors and availability , any one of these is used NEVER BOTH.

questions.text: 17-year-old Pushpa is admitted to the hospital due to lower extremity weakness. Onset of tingling in the patient's feet began 5 days ago, he then developed weakness 3 days ago and now he cannot stand or walk. He had an upper respiratory infection 2 weeks ago. Bilateral ankle and knee flexion/extension strength is 1/5, and hip flexors are 2/5. Reflexes are absent in the lower extremities. CSF results are as follows-Protein 200 mg/dL,Glucose 65 mg/dL,Leucocytes 1 /mm3, gram stain shows no bacteria .Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spirometry The patient is suffering from Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) As he has acute, ascending, symmetrical paralysis, LMN type (Flaccid, absent DTR) tingling in foot (some sensory symptom, with intact sensation) History of upper respiratory infection (trigger) . Also has increased protein with normal WBC count ( Albuminocytological dissociation ) Once GBS is suspected in a hemodynamically stable patient , the next step in management is to assess pulmonary function with spirometry . Forced vital capacity (FVC), and negative inspiratory force monitoring of respiratory muscle strength , and serial pulmonary function testing should be performed given the potential for rapid progression of disease. A decline in FVC ( < 20 mL/ kg ) indicates impending respiratory failure warranting endotracheal intubation.

Nerve conduction studies were normal in the arms and legs, except for absent F waves. She was unable to activate any muscles on electromyography (EMG), and no spontaneous activity was seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Guillain-Barré syndrome Patient is suffering from Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) As she has acute, ascending, a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis Respiratory paralysis Bifacial weakness (7th nerve palsy) History of diarrhea (trigger) . GUILLAIN-BARRÉ SYNDROME (GBS) is an acute, frequently severe, and fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy (Demyelinating) that is autoimmune in nature. Most sensitive test for diagnosis is Electrodiagnosis- showing finding suggestive of demyelination. - Increased f wave latency (earliest) -Prolong distal wave latency. -Decreased conduction velocity and conduction block. -Temporal dispersion -Normal amplitude (Axonal). Subtypes of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) SUBTYPE FEATURES ELECTRODIAGNOSIS PATHOLOGY Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP Adults affected more than children; 90% of cases in Western world; recovery rapid; anti-GM1 antibodies (<50%) Demyelinating First attack on Schwann cell surface; widespread myelin damage, macrophage activation, and lymphocytic infiltration; variable secondary axonal damage First attack at motor nodes of Ranvier; macrophage Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN Children and young adults; prevalent in China and Mexico; may be seasonal; recovery rapid; anti-GD1a antibodies Axonal First attack at motor nodes of Ranvier; macrophage activation, few lymphocytes, frequent periaxonal macrophages; extent of axonal damage highly variable Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN) Mostly adults; uncommon; recovery slow, often incomplete; closely related to AMAN Axonal Same as AMAN, but also affects sensory nerves and roots; axonal damage usually severe Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) Adults and children; ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia; anti-GQ1b antibodies (90%) Axonal or demyelinating Few cases examined; resembles AIDP
